head.title: A Computer Screen For Your Eyes Only

hedline.hl1: A Computer Screen For Your Eyes Only

abstract.p: Inviso Inc will soon introduce eShades, computer display that looks like pair of oversized sunglasses; Alfred Hildebrand, developer and co-founder of Inviso, comments; photos (S)

block.p: IF you use a laptop computer while traveling, other people may be looking over your shoulder. But eShades, which look like a pair of oversized sunglasses, let you switch off the laptop monitor and view sensitive material privately. And to the outside world, you might just look like Joe Cool.
When plugged into a laptop, eShades offer a large-screen viewing experience: the images look as if they are on a 19-inch monitor two and a half feet away.

IF you use a laptop computer while traveling, other people may be looking over your shoulder. But eShades, which look like a pair of oversized sunglasses, let you switch off the laptop monitor and view sensitive material privately. And to the outside world, you might just look like Joe Cool.
When plugged into a laptop, eShades offer a large-screen viewing experience: the images look as if they are on a 19-inch monitor two and a half feet away.

Alfred Hildebrand, the chairman of the eShades maker, Inviso Inc., a privately held company in Sunnyvale, Calif., has founded or worked with several companies involved in laser or optical technology. He was a co-founder of InViso in 1994, when he was a venture capital investor.

To combine the benefits of the fax machine and his pager's portability, Mr. Hildebrand developed small screens to allow a pager to receive a fax message. As portable communications devices proliferated, he then redesigned the displays for personal digital assistants and laptop computers. Mr. Hildebrand produced a final eShades prototype in May 2000. The glasses will be sold starting early next year.

The displays in eShades work much like traditional laptop displays. Liquid crystal is sandwiched between two pieces of glass, and a silicon chip imbedded in the glass transmits electronic signals that cue the crystal to create the desktop image. The flat-panel liquid crystal display is about an inch from each eye; an optical magnifier creates the feeling of a large display. ''It's like looking at a big-screen TV,'' Mr. Hildebrand said. Because the lighted image is so small, the battery uses only about a quarter of the power of conventional laptop displays.
EShades, which weigh about twice as much as regular sunglasses, will cost about $500, but Mr. Hildebrand expects the price to drop to about $300 ''sometime later on,'' he said.
